instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Liquid damage around <CAPACITOR>C7373</CAPACITOR> fixed problem

cpu Vore present 1,8V
Light in usb mouse
No pictures on external screen
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 3,4V

any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Does it chime? Known good LCD?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Don’t chime. Known good lcd yes. Also testing with external screen. 
Also caps look dose’t light up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: History? Liquid? BIOS messed with?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Liquid damage yes. And look like somebody have raped MagSafe hole.

mini display port is full off shit. 

Bios chip loking ok. I don’t have bios reader.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Corrosion, the usual suspects, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and traces to Y1905. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8. <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and all 16 termination resistors and traces, J6100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
No Title

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is low.. only 2,84v

on pictures <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Thats an ugly looking <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>, replace it. Not sure if low PP3V3 can cause the no post issues, but it might screw up some chips or logic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: I hope.. just order new one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is 3,3V 
still no chime and no screen. 
Could it be bad EFI?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Most likely not, in my experience it will usually show this symptoms when the SPI ROM is bad:

- Not enter S4
- Enters S0 and then goes back to S5
In some rare cases (bad ME) it might stay in S0 though, but this is probably one of the last things we should look into. I never had it happen for me

Did you inspect the clock IC (<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>), termination resistors and traces to the crystal like duke suggested?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Y1950 i get 0.940V on pin 1 and 4
J6100 i already have removed 
Will measuring <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> pin 8 what voltage should i have there ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Not important, its the clock for the camera. (Which is not enabled so probably about 0V)

You can't really see if the clock is working properly by checking it with a multimeter, best to use is a oscilloscope or if you have a fancy multimeter it might be able to show the clock frequency (But most multimeters won't go above the Khz's)

Since the USB mouse lights up I'm having some doubts that it could be <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, but it was worth checking. Any idea of there was liquid around that area?
Have you checked the SPI termination resistors?

Maybe Duke has a better idea though, lets see what he has to say :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
Maybe ther could been some liquid around.
Also found a broken <CAPACITOR>C8351</CAPACITOR>.
But that has noting to do with no posting..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: It could be anything. Dead <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, crap under the SMC, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> termination resistors/traces, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and what not. USB mouse lighting up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
So I can try reflow smc? (Have tried smc bypass with no luck)
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> give voltage on all pins <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looking fine (don't know how to measure that)

Yes light in USB mouse. CPU getting little hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Uhh if a USB mouse lights the machine is kind of working. Connect a keyboard and do a PRAM reset and see if chime returns.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Have tried pram reset with a know good keyboard. Still no chime or pictures.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Do it with an external keyboard. Also check if that mouse does not light on a dead board or a board without RAM inserted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: tried with external keyboard still no pictures and chime. Also tried mouse in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board without RAM and it light up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: Alright so the light on the mouse tells us nothing, it will only tell the system is powering USB ports :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: ok. then i give up this card. *close*

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
You can try to flash a clean rom onto the SPI though, that would be my last guess before I'd give up.

Just to be sure since I don't think you confirmed this yet, but you did check the SPI termination resistors right?
